BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights:
The visible wind slabs of the last few days represent the main danger.
Backcountry touring calls for extensive experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The wind will be moderate over a wide area. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in all aspects above the tree line.
Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large avalanches are possible adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. The wind slabs of the last few days can be released even by a single winter sport participant in all aspects.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The wind has transported the new snow significantly. New snow and wind slabs are lying mostly on an icy crust. Weak layers exist in the snowpack. In the course of the day the wind slabs will increase in size additionally.
In many places there is a danger of falling on the icy crust.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The wind will be moderate over a wide area. The avalanche danger will not decrease for the time being.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Over a wide area up to 50 cm of snow has fallen above approximately 1900 m. The strong wind has transported a lot of snow. In the last three days large surface-area wind slabs formed in particular adjacent to ridgelines. The fresh wind slabs can be released even by a single winter sport participant at elevated altitudes. At high altitude and in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The new snow can be released by a single winter sport participant in particular on steep shady slopes. Over a wide area new snow is lying on a weakly bonded old snowpack. As a consequence of a sometimes strong wind, easily released wind slabs formed. Gliding avalanches are possible below approximately 1700 m.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Snow sport activities outside marked and open pistes call for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The large quantity of fresh snow and the extensive wind slabs are bonding only slowly with the old snowpack. The avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found in particular at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, when entering gullies and bowls for example and on very steep shady slopes. Single skiers can release avalanches easily, including large ones.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs are to be evaluated with care and prudence.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Since Saturday the wind has been moderate to strong. In gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain the wind slabs have increased in size. They can be released by a single winter sport participant.
In some cases the wind slabs have bonded still only poorly with each other and the old snowpack.
Fresh snow and large quantities of wind-drifted snow of the last few days must be evaluated with care and prudence. More dry avalanches are possible, but they can be large.
Backcountry touring calls for careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on a weakly bonded old snowpack. Individual weak layers exist in the snowpack on wind-loaded slopes.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs represent the main danger. They are covered with new snow and therefore difficult to recognise.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The new snow-covered wind slabs of last week are lying on soft layers in particular on north to east to southwest facing aspects above approximately 2000 m. They can be released even by a single winter sport participant.
The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular on steep slopes and in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Weak layers exist in the top section of the snowpack here.
Defensive route selection is appropriate.
On very steep slopes only isolated small and medium-sized natural avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
10 to 20 cm of snow has fallen since Friday above approximately 2000 m.
The upper section of the snowpack is unfavourably layered. Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on soft layers. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly with the old snowpack. Since Wednesday on wind-loaded slopes numerous small and medium-sized avalanches were released.
The old snowpack is hard. Snow depths vary greatly at high altitude, depending on the infuence of the wind.
5 to 15 cm of snow will fall until Wednesday above approximately 1500 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: Little snow will fall until late morning. The avalanche danger will persist.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Light snowfall to low altitudes.
In some cases the wind slabs have bonded still only poorly with the old snowpack. The fresh snow of the last few days as well as the sometimes deep wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in particular in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain and on wind-loaded slopes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on the smooth surface of an old snowpack. In particular at elevated altitudes snow depths vary greatly, depending on the infuence of the wind. In particular at low altitude thus far only a little snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights:
The visible wind slabs of the last few days represent the main danger.
Backcountry touring calls for extensive experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The wind will be moderate over a wide area. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in all aspects above approximately 1400 m.
Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large avalanches are possible adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. The wind slabs of the last few days can be released even by a single winter sport participant in all aspects.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The wind has transported the new snow significantly. New snow and wind slabs are lying mostly on an icy crust. Weak layers exist in the snowpack. In the course of the day the wind slabs will increase in size additionally.
In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the icy crust.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The wind will be moderate over a wide area. The avalanche danger will not decrease for the time being.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released easily. In addition a certain danger of dry loose snow avalanches exists.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. As a consequence of new snow and wind, easily released wind slabs formed in the last few days above the tree line. This also applies in areas close to the tree line, in the regions exposed to a lot of wind especially. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude.

As a consequence of solar radiation more frequent small and medium-sized dry loose snow avalanches are to be expected. This applies in particular on extremely steep sunny slopes.

In addition a latent danger of gliding avalanches exists, in particular on steep east, south and west facing slopes below approximately 2600 m. In isolated cases the gliding avalanches are quite large. This applies in the regions with a lot of snow. Caution is to be exercised in areas with glide cracks.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 20 to 50 cm of snow fell in the last few days above approximately 1000 m. The wind was light to moderate over a wide area. The wind was moderate to strong in some regions. The fresh wind slabs are lying on soft layers. They can be released easily.

The new snow is lying on surface hoar in some places in areas close to the tree line. The new snow of last week is lying on a crust in all aspects below approximately 2600 m. The old snowpack will be stable over a wide area.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The fresh and older wind slabs remain in some cases prone to triggering. The danger of dry loose snow avalanches will decrease gradually.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs must be evaluated with care and prudence. The new snow of the last three days can be released easily.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: In some regions 70 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen above approximately 1700 m. At high altitude and in the regions exposed to heavier precipitation the avalanche prone locations are more prevalent. The fresh wind slabs can be released even by a single winter sport participant at elevated altitudes.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The new snow can be released by a single winter sport participant in particular on steep shady slopes. As a consequence of a sometimes strong wind, easily released wind slabs formed. Gliding avalanches are possible below approximately 1700 m. In particular at low altitude a little snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Snow sport activities outside marked and open pistes call for experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The new snow and wind slabs represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The large quantity of fresh snow and the extensive wind slabs are bonding only slowly with the old snowpack. The avalanche prone locations for dry avalanches are to be found in particular at transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, when entering gullies and bowls for example and on very steep shady slopes. Single skiers can release avalanches easily, including large ones.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights:
The visible wind slabs of the last few days represent the main danger.
Backcountry touring calls for extensive experience in the assessment of avalanche danger and careful route selection.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The wind will be moderate over a wide area. The avalanche prone locations are to be found in all aspects above approximately 1500 m.
Medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large avalanches are possible adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls. The wind slabs of the last few days can be released even by a single winter sport participant in all aspects.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The wind has transported the new snow significantly. In the course of the day the wind slabs will increase in size additionally.
In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the icy crust.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment:
The wind will be moderate over a wide area. The avalanche danger will not decrease for the time being.
Below approximately 1400 m only a little snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released easily. In addition a certain danger of dry loose snow avalanches exists.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Fresh wind slabs represent the main danger. As a consequence of new snow and wind, easily released wind slabs formed in the last few days above the tree line. This also applies in areas close to the tree line, in the regions exposed to a lot of wind especially. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. The number and size of avalanche prone locations will increase with altitude.

As a consequence of solar radiation more frequent small and medium-sized dry loose snow avalanches are to be expected. This applies in particular on extremely steep sunny slopes.

In addition a latent danger of gliding avalanches exists, in particular on steep east, south and west facing slopes below approximately 2600 m. In isolated cases the gliding avalanches are quite large. This applies in the regions with a lot of snow. Caution is to be exercised in areas with glide cracks.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 20 to 50 cm of snow fell in the last few days above approximately 1000 m. The wind was light to moderate over a wide area. The wind was moderate to strong in some regions. The fresh wind slabs are lying on soft layers. They can be released easily.

The new snow is lying on surface hoar in some places in areas close to the tree line. The new snow of last week is lying on a crust in all aspects below approximately 2600 m. The old snowpack will be stable over a wide area.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: The fresh and older wind slabs remain in some cases prone to triggering. The danger of dry loose snow avalanches will decrease gradually.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow represents the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Down to 800 m and below snow will fall over a wide area.
In particular in the regions with a lot of snow more medium-sized and, in isolated cases, large dry avalanches are possible as a consequence of new snow and wind.
The fresh wind slabs can be released, even by small loads in isolated cases.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Over a wide area 30 to 50 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, has fallen since Friday.
In isolated cases new snow is lying on a hard crust. In all regions only a small amount of snow is lying for the time of year.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Fresh wind slabs require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: As a consequence of a strong wind, mostly small wind slabs formed above the tree line. As a consequence of foehn wind, small wind slabs will form also in areas close to the tree line. These can be released in isolated cases. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. In the regions neighbouring those that are subject to danger level 3 (considerable) and at elevated altitudes the avalanche danger is a little higher.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
The wind was strong over a wide area.
In the last few days hard wind slabs formed especially above approximately 2000 m. Wind slabs are lying on soft layers.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The fresh snow and the wind slabs that are forming above all adjacent to ridgelines in all aspects represent the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: The fresh snow and the mostly small wind slabs can be released by a single winter sport participant in isolated cases in particular on steep, little used north, northeast and northwest facing slopes above approximately 2000 m.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The old snowpack will be favourable at intermediate and high altitudes. In particular adjacent to ridgelines and in gullies and bowls as well as at high altitude mostly small wind slabs will form.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Restraint should be exercised because avalanches can sweep people along and give rise to falls.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
Some snow has fallen since Friday.
In steep terrain there is a danger of falling on the hard snow surface. These avalanche prone locations are covered with new snow and are difficult to recognise. Backcountry touring calls for restraint.
Several small and, in isolated cases, medium-sized dry avalanches are possible.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
Above approximately 1000 m snow has fallen since Friday over a wide area. Thus far only a little snow is lying.
Over a wide area from a snow sport perspective, in most cases insufficient snow is lying.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The wind slabs represent the main danger. These places are covered with new snow and are therefore barely recognisable.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The new snow and wind slabs are lying on a crust in all aspects.
The wind slabs can be released in isolated cases at their margins. Especially transitions into gullies and bowls transitions from a shallow to a deep snowpack, especially on very steep slopes. They are covered with new snow and therefore difficult to recognise.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
5 to 15 cm of snow has fallen since Friday above approximately 2000 m.
Over a wide area new snow and wind slabs are lying on a hard crust.
Snow depths vary greatly at high altitude, depending on the infuence of the wind. In some cases the wind slabs have bonded poorly with the old snowpack.
Especially on steep sunny slopes only a little snow is lying. Also adjacent to ridgelines hardly any snow is lying.
In its middle, the snowpack is fairly homogeneous and its surface consists of loosely bonded snow lying on a crust that is strong in many cases. This applies below approximately 2600 m.
2 to 10 cm of snow will fall until Wednesday above approximately 1500 m.
BulletinMeasurements.tendencyComment: In some localities a little new snow: The avalanche danger will persist.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: Wind slabs require caution.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment:
The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs can be released in isolated cases, especially at their margins. Caution is to be exercised in particular adjacent to ridgelines in gullies and bowls, and behind abrupt changes in the terrain. Mostly avalanches are small.
In the regions neighbouring those that are subject to danger level 3 (considerable) and at elevated altitudes the avalanche danger is a little higher.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment:
10 to 20 cm of snow, and even more in some localities, fell in the last few days above approximately 1000 m. The wind was moderate to strong in some regions.
The fresh and somewhat older wind slabs are lying on soft layers. The old snowpack will be quite stable.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: The old snowpack will be quite favourable.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: The conditions are mostly favourable.

BulletinMeasurements.avActivityHighlights: New snow represents the main danger.
BulletinMeasurements.avActivityComment: Thus far only isolated small avalanches are possible as a consequence of the new snow.
BulletinMeasurements.snowpackStructureComment: Some snow fell on Sunday. 5 to 10 cm of snow has fallen above approximately 1200 m. The weather conditions will foster a gradual strengthening of the snowpack. In isolated cases new snow is lying on a moist old snowpack.
